text: The streets of Rome are locked in a 3AM traffic jam. MUSI spills from cafes and discotheques. We DESCEND further...

...into sidewalks overflowing with prostitutes, B-movie s mafiosi, down-on-their-luck royalty and paparazzi darting between cars on Vespa scooters. And now, from out of the crowd, something even stranger emerges:
in his mid-teens, at once streetwise and innocent. A skin kid in worn jeans with iron-on patches on the knees. The streetwalkers in their platform shoes call out to him:
Ciao, Paolo! The kid smiles bashfully as they fall in around him.
Che magro, che vergogna! So skinny. Paolo, bambino, why don't you let us make you breakfast? We'd look after you real nice.
(smiles, blushing) I bet you would. A car pulls up to the curb: it's time for the girls to go back to work. Maria-Donna pulls Paul close, serious now:
Hurry home, Paolo, eh? The street is no place for a boy like you. Don't make your poor mamma worry.

I can take care of myself. Ciao, Maria-Donna. Paul walks on, leaving the girls to haggle with their joh He pulls out a folded-over issue of Fantastic Comics and walks away into the darkened, narrow Via dei Bauillari.

flicker to life behind him. Paul walks on, oblivious, immersed in his comic book. The car creeps forward. The headlights like owl's-eyes. A white Fiat 600. It drives up behind him. Hovering. A man climbs out. He wears a red ski mask.
Paul?

Yeah -- ? Paul turns and sees them. A moment -- and then he runs. In an instant, they are upon him. The boy flails, kicking and writhing to buck them off. He's got a lot of fight in him for such a skinny kid; it's as if he knew this was co They open the trunk and shove Paul inside. He doesn't fit Someone sits down on the trunk. The latch clicks: it's closed. The men pull off their mas Their eyes are black and wild with adrenaline. They climb into the car.
Avanti! Go!
clatters into its cradle. We TILT UP to reveal a flustere young SECRETARY in red lipstick and a tight sweater. She rises from her desk, overwhelmed, and she begins to run.

A sprawling 400-year-old mansioned estate surrounded by gardens and statuary. The secretary runs across the grounds in her high heels. She runs past a row of ancient busts of Roman emperors. She runs past a full-grown male LION pacing in a gilded c She runs past a swimming pool ringed by lounging STARLETS She trips and stumbles as she breaks a heel. She reaches down, pulls her shoes off, and runs in her nylons --
-- up the stairs of the mansion, past walls cluttered wit vast art collection. She runs down the hallway --

-- and opens the door to a huge room, empty but for a Lou XIV desk, a phone and an old-time paper-tape stock ticker A man in a bespoke suit stands at the window, gazing out upon his estate. The paper tape from the stock ticker sna across the room and through his fingertips. He whispers price quotes to himself, like a monk saying the rosary.

I'm sorry, Mr Getty. I should have knocked but -- it's -- J. PAUL GETTY turns and cocks an eyebrow. His gaze is qui and focused; he has the impatience of a man whose mind is always sixty seconds ahead of whomever he's listening to.
To the point, Nancy, the market's open.
They've -- He's been kidnapped! Paul, Little Paul, your grandson, in Rome my God he's just a child -- The ticker-tape in Getty's hands stops moving.
They need to speak with you, it's very urgent. The Italian police, the boy's mother, they're on the phone right now. A tremor of emotion in Getty's eyes. Then it's gone.
I'm not available. The Secretary stares at him.
Excuse me, Mr. Getty?
The door, Nancy. She closes the door as the tape in the Getty's fingertips starts to move again. We hear young Paul in VOICE-OVER:
To be a Getty is an extraordinary thing.
The little Fiat 600 (with Paul in the trunk) drives throu a toll gate and onto the great Italian highway.
I know that because my grandpa told me so.
J Paul Getty and the young Paul walk down a dark tunnel.
You're a Getty, Paul. A Getty is special. A Getty has a destiny. A Getty is nobody's fool. The boy gazes up at his grandfather reverently.
You see, my grandpa wasn't just the richest man in the world. He was the richest man in the history of the world.
SAND DUNES undulate endlessly unto the horizon. We SOAR OVER THEM until we find a singular figure standing amidst the shifting sands: J Paul Getty.

My grandpa was the one who brought the oil out of the Saudi desert. Everybody knew it was there, they just thought it couldn't be done. We CRANE over the dunes to REVEAL a great city of refiner and pumping oil derricks belching flame, a mirage seeming summoned forth by Getty's will alone.
But Grandpa found a way. He made a deal with the Bedouin tribes. But there was so much oil there was no ship big enough to carry it all.
Getty supervises construction of a SUPERTANKER, a behemot the size of a skyscraper lying on its side.
So my grandfather invented one. He called it the supertanker.
As we soar over the American intercontinental highway, SE STATIONS materialize out of nowhere, dotting the landscap all bearing the Getty name.
Then he built a chain of service stations across America with his name on them. Grandpa controlled every drop of oil, from beneath the earth to the customer's gas tank. (a beat) And he was famous.
In a series of B&W still images accompanying the pages of THE PLAYBOY INTERVIEW -- click click click -- Getty holds forth on his great wealth.
Mr. Getty, rumor has it that you are the first man in history with a fortune in excess of one billion dollars. How much money do you have?
I have no idea. If you can count your money, you're not a billionaire.
The little Fiat 600 winds along the serpentine Italian highway, its headlights blazing.

I'm telling you this so you can understand the things you're about to see. And maybe you can forgive us. We PULL BACK as the Fiat winds along the autostrada, away from the glowing city, until it vanishes into the dark.
It's like we're from another planet where the force of gravity is so strong it bends the light. It bends people too. We look like you, but we're not like you. (MORE )
(a beat) But we were, once.
lies sleeping in a beauty mask as her three children, PAU (9), MARK (4), and ARIADNE (2) bounce on the bed, clamori for breakfast. Her husband lies beside her. Gail GROANS:
Too early. The sun's not even up. Back to bed, you little monsters. Little Paul peels back one eye of Gail's mask and lets th sunlight in. She recoils.
You made your point. But no pancakes.

QUICK CUTS: Gail fixes pancakes for the children and a cu of strong black coffee for herself, cleans up empty wineglasses and ashtrays from the party the night before, downs two aspirin, puts a samba LP on the Hi-Fi, washes u dresses the children, pulls on capris, teases her hair, a does a quick little bossa-nova with the children.
Now, you'll have to amuse yourselves quietly. I have work to do this morning and I am not to be disturbed.

Gail works with pastels at an easel, copying from a posed photo of a model in a cocktail dress (the music PLAYS OVE from the previous scene, and throughout this whole sequen It's catalog work, but Gail's got a gift for line and ges she has style. Her kids draw on the floor alongside her, copying everything she does. Little Paul especially.
Gail is on the phone, a utility bill in her hand.
Look in your file and you'll find that we've been very good customers of Southern California Edison. We're good people.  7. In the sunlight we can see the words PAST DUE written the

And I have a little boy who's concerned that if the lights aren't on for Christmas Santa might not find his way here. Everything about Gail -- her Seven Sisters accent, her finishing school posture -- reeks of the former debutante
If we could make the minimum payment we wouldn't need an extension. We do want to pay something, though. We notice who the bill is addressed to: JOHN PAUL GETTY,
Tell me, Mrs Getty. What does your husband do?
He's a poet. A good one.
Any relation to the oil man Getty? She considers her answer carefully.
Distant.
(laughs) Must be, right?
Gail piles all three children into a Ford Fairlane. She holds the electric bill in her hand, along with her drawi
Gail hands over her drawings. The girl at the desk pays $ apiece, in cash. Gail wouldn't dream of counting the mone
Gail counts the money. She stuffs it in the tray at the payment window. She thumbs through what's left.

Gail walks through Beverly Hills with her three children tow. She passes a store window and stops. It's Givenchy.  8. She gazes longingly at the window display of a woman in a sapphire evening gown... and then we RACK FOCUS to the mo with three kids reflected in the glass.
Are we going home now?
One last stop, darling.

Gail approaches the building's registry, with her childre in tow. She steps closer. She takes off her sunglasses. There, encased beneath glass, are the white letters press into black felt: GETTY OIL CORPORATION -- 28TH FLOOR.
Excuse me, miss. May I help you?
Gail and her children stand out on the sidewalk, squintin up at the 20-story glass tower that looms above them.
Must be eighty stories at least. How many stories is it, Mom?
I don't know, darling. An awful lot of stories.
What are we looking for, Mom? Gail puts her sunglasses back on.
Your grandfather.
I've never even met the man. JOHN PAUL GETTY II (known in the family as "Big Paul") is young, bearded and handsome, his feet propped up on the w ads on the coffee table before him.

You know he refused to pay my mother a nickel of child support.  9. Big Paul climbs out of his chair and digs around inside t desk drawers. The apartment is warm, bohemian, filled wit paintings and books and music on the record player.

When I was a boy, I would send my father letters. "Dear Daddy, how I wish I could meet you. I'1l be waiting for you at the baseball diamond," that sort of thing. (a beat) You know what he sent back? He hands Gail a letter. It's in little-boy handwriting, o lined paper -- but marked up with red ink.
He mailed it back with the spelling corrected. Nothing else.
He is your father, that's got to count for something, Paul, the rent is due and Christmas is coming.
What would you have me do, Gail? Accost him on the street?

We write him a letter and ask for a job. Any job. And this time, we'll get the spelling right. Gail goes to his chair, sits on his lap, and kisses him. looks up at her: she's not an easy woman to say no to.
You were never meant to be poor, Gail. I know that.
We're not poor. We're broke. There's a difference.
I don't want to be an oil man.
I don't want you to either. I love you the way you are. All we need is enough to get by, but we're not getting by.
I'm sorry, Gail.  10.
I'm tired of struggling. I'm ready for a different kind of life. Big Paul gets up, picks up the bottle of Chianti from the coffee table, and goes to the bedroom. We HOLD on Gail.
Gail sets her husband's Smith-Corona down on the carpet. She inserts a clean page into the carriage.

Dear Dad -- Father -- For years I struggled to understand why you kept your distance. Now I know you were giving me a chance to prove myself, on my own, free from the shadow of your achievements -- no, great -- (backspace, retypes) -- immense achievements. I understand now what a sacrifice that must have been for you. She kneels before the typewriter, a pretty witch conjurin spirits.

Now that I am a man, I have nothing left to prove, except to you. Let me prove myself to you, Father. (a beat) As always, your loving -- no, your loyal son: John Paul Getty Two. She RIPS the page from the carriage and we
MUSIC. Big Paul reaches into the fridge and pops the top a can of Schlitz. Gail is making dinner on the stove. Big Paul slips his hands beneath her sweater to warm them.

God, your hands are cold! Stop, the kids are -- I'm serious, you -- Gail wriggles free and Big Paul dances her around the apartment to the BEACH BOYS' CHRISTMAS ALBUM as the child look on. There's a tree with presents beneath it.
(singing along) He's the man with all the toys ...  11. Gail gazes up at him, starry-eyed: for this one moment, a is right with the world. The BUZZER rings.
That'll be Ms. Canzanelli telling us she's calling the police. (pressing the button) We're so sorry about the noise --
I have a car waiting for Mr. John Paul Getty the Second, if you please.
"The Second?" Little Paul goes to the window.
Down in the street, look -- OUTSIDE, a ROLLS-ROYCE PHANTOM is idling in the street.
Oh my God, somebody died.
(realizing) No, baby. We've been sent for.
As "The Man With All The Toys" continues to play, the lit family rides in the back of the Rolls, along with their hastily-packed bags. The kids exchange a look. Up ahead they see it --
A LEARJET 23 private plane idling on the runway. The Roll drives right up to the clamshell airstair.
Little Paul wakes up in the back of another limousine. Th other kids gaze amazedly out the window, their breath fog the glass. Reflected in the window is the Roman coliseum.
A luxurious Roman hotel, with a mustached CONCIERGE waiti to receive them. A BELLMAN takes their bags.
Signore Getty is awaiting you.  12.
Parked outside the door is a room-service cart piled high with dirty trays. A "NON DISTURBARE" sign hangs from the doorknob. The Concierge KNOCKS gently. We PUSH into

A CLOTHESLINE is strung across the length of the room, fr which are suspended a line of MEN'S UNDERPANTS on clothes Empty food containers and clothes are everywhere. And everywhere there is art: paintings and artifacts prop against the walls. Little Paul reaches into the mess and pulls out a small statuette lying on the floor: it's a MINOTAUR carved out of marble.
(taking it from him) Don't touch that, sweetheart. Let's just keep our hands to ourselves. It's dirty. (examining it) And old. Possibly priceless.
I deplore that word. They turn to see Getty emerge from the bedroom, freshly groomed and powdered.
I'm sorry?

Dirty and old I have no problem with at all. In fact I have some affection for them as they're the words most frequently used to describe me, along with rich. Getty goes to the mirror, inserts a tie bar into his coll

But priceless -- that's another thing entirely. People say priceless when what they really mean to say that something is invaluable, or irreplaceable. That Minotaur statuette in your hands, for instance, dates from 460BC; there are only a handful like it remaining, and none in such pristine condition. I'm sure those fuckers at the Met or the British Museum would kill to get their greasy paws on it.  13.
He just said --
Paul.
Would you care to guess what I paid for it?
I wouldn't know where to begin.
Oh, you're too modest. You've got taste, I can tell. I think you know a good deal about art.
I do. I just don't know what it costs.
Well then, you'll learn. Come on, indulge an old fool. What do you think I paid?
Five hundred thousand dollars.

Eleven dollars and twenty-three cents. I picked it up in the black market in Heraklion. This cripple was asking seventeen dollars for it and it took me an hour to bring him down to his bottom line. At Sotheby's today I'd hazard it'd bring $1.2 million. (a beat) You see, priceless is such an insipid word. Everything has a price. The great struggle in life is coming to grips with what that price is. He crouches down and offers the figurine to Little Paul.
I want you to have it.
We couldn't.
Do you like it, Paul?
That's OK. I don't need it.  14.
I insist.
I insist. We can't. It's far too extravagant for a little boy.
For most little boys, it would be. Getty hands the boy the statue.
But not for a Getty. Little Paul takes the figurine; it's done. They're forced to accept it. Gail and Big Paul smile awkwardly.
Thank you. We'll treasure it.
Thanks are for strangers. You're family. You're my family. Come here, let me look at you. (brings Big Paul close) Son. My son. My grandson. (to Gail) My daughter.
Daughter-in-law, I'm afraid.
Nonsense. You're not just some district judge's daughter anymore. You're one of our family now. Getty turns to his son:

I had to focus on my mission, you understand. My business. I couldn't be weighed down, mentally, with a family. There was work to be done. You understand that, don't you. Big Paul is silent. Getty darkens, glowering, then walks away, pushing the clothesline aside as he crosses the roo
Pardon the laundry. I wash my undershorts myself, in the bathroom sink. (MORE )

I see no reason to pay ten dollars to have room service launder them when I can do it myself for a few lira. What kind of rube do they take me for? Which reminds me -- He takes out a small notebook and golf pencil and writes entry: LAUNDRY SOAP -- 22 LIRA.

It's tax-deductible. Almost everything is, if you know how to play it. What in hell are we doing standing around in this dusty old hotel room? We should be celebrating. That's what families do, right?
After that, everything changed.
Gail throws open the windows. The family is moving into a light-filled apartment. Gail is unpacking when she finds

Dad became an executive in Grandpa's company. Mom found us an apartment near the Piazza Navona. -- the Minotaur figurine wrapped in her scarf. It makes h anxious. She finds a shoebox and stashes it in the closet
And Grandpa started my education.
We return to the SILHOUETTES of Getty and Paul as they wa hand-in-hand through the darkened, ancient tunnel.
Come on, I want to show you something. We FOLLOW them through the mouth of the tunnel. They look out upon it: the boy is awed.
What is it?
It's home. We step out into the sunlight of  16.
AN ANCIENT ROMAN VILLA in the mountains overlooking Rome, ringed by statues of the Roman gods. Getty leads Paul on house tour:
This is where I slept with my wife, Sabina. This here is where I ate roast wild boar with my generals. This is where I made love to my concubines. And this is where I took my baths.
You used to live here?

In the second century, when I was the Emperor Hadrian. I knew it the moment I first visited this place. I remembered every stone as clearly as if I'd just come back from a trip to the store for a pack of smokes. I never felt at home anywhere on Earth until I came here.
Maybe they'd let you stay. Overnight, like. Get a tent and a sleeping bag --
Oh, I tried, believe me. I made them an offer, a very generous offer!
Them?
Rome. The Romans. But when they hear the name Getty they all get dollar signs in their eyes. They said it wasn't for sale.
Figures.

Exactly. That old tactic. That's what I'm talking about, Paul. (a beat) To be a Getty is to have everyone you know secretly want a piece of you. You are surrounded, always, by smiling faces, but you have no one.  17.
You have us.

(deeply moved) That's true. I have you now. And to think it was almost too late. All I've built would crumble into dust if there's no one to carry it on after I'm gone. (takes Paul's hand) The blood of emperors runs through you, as it does through me. You're a Getty, Paul. You have a destiny.

Gail, Big Paul and the children descend the gangplank ont 47-foot yacht. Beautiful COUPLES and their children are already relaxing on deck with cocktails and music. ISABEL and JULIAN, the hosts, wave happily as they descend.
Jules, it's the Gettys! (kisses, greetings) We were worried you'd been abducted.
If I were you I'd make us walk the plank.
Not until we've got a few drinks in you first. And this must be John Paul II?
And III. Charmed LAUGHTER. Big Paul looks a bit taken aback.
No Roman numerals, please. We're American. Just Paul is fine, for both of us.

Bronzed bodies lie in the sun alongside sweating gin-and- tonics as the yacht glides over a stained-glass sea. Litt Paul tiptoes over and around them -- -- to the bow of the boat, where Gail stands, wearing a w shift dress, her eyes closed: an Aegean goddess. She sees Little Paul, holds out her hand to him, and brings him cl  18.
I feel like we're flying.
Me too, darling. (whispers) The whole world, for you. She hold him as they gaze into the approaching horizon.

Getty, Little Paul, and Big Paul all sit at the breakfast table, attended by BULLIMORE, a butler in a morning coat. Getty eats a half grapefruit. Big Paul seems hung over. Little Paul eats Cheerios as he reads Getty's mail to him

вЂњDear Mr. Getty, I am writing you because we are in desperate straits. My husband suffers from a tumor that has caused his groin area to swell to uncontrollable dimensions. The doctors say without immediate surgery normal movement will soon become impossible. God bless you, you are a Great American, Elvira Broadus, Mound City, Arkansas." Getty dictates as the boy transcribes his response:

Dear Mrs. Broadus, while I am sympathetic to your unique situation, you are one of three thousand people daily who write to me asking for money. If I were to respond to every request for money I receive, I would soon be as destitute as yourself. The boy seems slightly downcast.
Yours, JP Getty. Next. The boy places the form letter into an envelope, addresse it, and sets it on a pile of identical letters. Little Pa picks up a new letter and opens it.
вЂњDear Mr. Getty --"
Surely you can find someone else to answer your mail.  19.
I like it, Dad.

He likes it, son. The boy wants to be useful. I find that admirable. It's a family business. Everyone has a role to play. Which reminds me: I'm firing Howard Larkin. I'm making you Executive Vice President of Getty Oil, with oversight over European operations and exploration.
All I know about oil is regular or unleaded.
You wanted a job. I'm giving you one. Sink or swim. BLACK OUT.

location: LE PALAIS DU ZAHIR, MARRAKECH, MOROCCO

text: CLOSE on Little Paul's sleeping face. He is older now, al in his teens. His eyes open. He sits up and looks around. We are in a vast room piled with pillows and carpets, and people sleeping upon them. Thick smoke hangs in the air.
Paul pours a bowl of cereal. There are others here, shirt skinny men with beards and long hair; he doesn't know the

A huge round bed within a tent-like canopy of brocaded si dominates the room. A man and a woman are sleeping there. Paul lifts the flap of the canopy and climbs into the bed with his cereal. We realize that, beneath the long hair a the beard, the man is Big Paul, his father.

(whispering) Dad. (increasing volume) Dad. Dad. Dad. Big Paul does not move. Little Paul turns and looks at th woman beside him; she is not his mother, but a remarkable dark-haired beauty, a model.  20. Upon the nightstand there's a glass of wine, a lighter, a glassine bag, a burnt spoon.
Dad. Dad. Dad. Finally, Paul realizes it's pointless and gives up.
Gail Getty paces in the front lobby of Getty's headquarte
This poor woman, what she has endured! Gail is impeccably dressed and attended by her Italian attorney, the high-strung, diminutive GIOVANNI IACOVONI.
The decadence of the father, a depraved drug addict, living ina palace in Marrakech filled with hippie parasites. How she suffers with worry for her son!
Giovanni, enough. This isn't Italy. We're not going before the Pope for an annulment.
I know this, signora. I do this simply to get my blood flowing.
It's all business to them. A TEAM OF SUITS file past en route to the conference room
I wonder how many people have ever managed to walk out of that conference room in one piece.
Signora. Do not underestimate the power of a mother's love.
Right now I'd rather have a billionaire's money.
Ms Getty, they're ready for you now.  21.
A long conference table, lined on either side with ATTORN At one end sits Gail Getty, with Iacovoni by her side.

Of course, we expect Ms. Getty will be seeking a generous financial settlement, as is typical in high- profile divorce cases. At the other end sits J Paul Getty, silent and aloof. Bes him, his lead attorney, OSWALD HINGE.
As pertains to custody, there is the matter of Ms. Getty's fitness as a mother.
The father is a drug addict who cannot tie his own shoes. You would leave the boy alone in Morocco with a rich degenerate?
The court will take a close interest in her psychological profile. We are asking the judge to order a complete evaluation by a panel of psychiatrists.

Ms Harris suffers from a common affliction among the intelligent women, which is to fall in love with lo imbrogliare, losers, bums. Aside from this, she is in perfect mental health, you know this as well as I do. You are simply stalling, using the boy as a bargaining chip.
We have all the time in the world.
(vising) We will see you before the judge.
A deal. All eyes turn toward Gail.
Did you say something?  22.
The offer I'm about to make expires at the end of business today.
Gail, please --
What is your offer, Ms. Harris?
Nothing. You pay nothing. No settlement, no alimony, no community property, no child support, nothing. Getty breaks in:
I don't get it.
In exchange, I want my son on a plane back home tonight. And full custody.
What's your game?
I don't want your money.
Everybody wants my money.
You want your money. I want Paul. We can both have what we want.
I sense I'm being taken, I just don't know how.
Mr. Getty, why don't we take this under advisement. Gail removes her jewelry -- her engagement ring, earrings and sets them on the table before her.

I've watched you for years. You can't help yourself. Stiffing the bellboy. Re-using your dental floss. Searching other people's seat cushions for loose change -- Getty darkens. Gail changes tack, flattering him:  23.

You didn't get where you are without a healthy regard for the value of a dollar. You know a bargain when you see one. You know how to seize the initiative when your opponent is at his weakest. What I'm offering is the greatest bargain you're ever going to get. But free never lasts. She rises, leaving the jewelry on the table. Iacovoni tri to interrupt, but she ignores him.
Six o'clock. HOLD on Getty. Over the sound of a PLANE LANDING we CUT T
Little Paul emerges from the gate into Gail's arms. She holds him tightly, exhausted and relieved. For a moment, accepts her embrace, but then:
I wanted to stay.
Let's just go home, OK?

I was happy with Dad and Talitha. Why'd you have to ruin it? He pulls away from her. As they walk through the airport, Paul walks on ahead, pulling farther away from her. Gail begins to reach out for him, but stops herself, givi him his freedom, until he is nearly lost in the crowd.

Gail has been up all night. We have come full circle now, and have returned to the night of Paul's disappearance. Gail stands in the door of Paul's room, gazing at his bed which has not been slept in. Her other two kids are aslee

Call me if you hear from him. No questions asked. Just tell him to come home. Gail hangs up the phone. She closes Paul's address book. QUICK CUTS: with no other way to fill her time, she tries work at her drafting table. She can't focus.  24. She cleans the bathroom instead. She washes the sheets in the sink.
Gail lies passed out on the bathroom floor, still wearing her rubber gloves. The apartment is immaculate. The kitchen phone RINGS. She wakes, rises, goes to it.
Yes. Si? The low VOICE on the other end speaks English with an acc
Signora. We have your son.
Oh, God, thank you. Is he all right?
Signora, we are kidnappers and have him captive. A long silence.
Are you still there?
Is this some kind of joke?
No.
There must be some mistake.
No mistake. He is not harmed. We will send proof in the coming days.
Who are you?
I am Cinquanta. Paul is safe, but it will require $17 million to release him. Go to the police if you like, it makes no difference.
I don't have any money.  25.
Get it from your father-in-law. He has all the money in the world. DIAL TONE. In the distance, we hear a SIREN approaching.
The PHONE CLATTERS into the receiver again. The secretary runs across the grounds, past the lion, up the stairs.
Getty sits at his desk, his phone to his ear.
They're here, Mr Getty.
Getty walks down a long mirrored corridor. He buttons his jacket, straightens his tie, shoots his cuffs.

A throne room, literally. The chamber is lined with enorm tapestries and gilt mirrors. One side of the room is empty, the other packed with a ra of Fleet Street news reporters. When Getty enters, they start baying like hounds for his attention:
Mr. Getty! Mr Getty! How much is the ransom for your grandson?
I don't know. I'll bet it's a lot.
Gail is in the kitchen with the phone receiver pressed to her ear, her eyes closed. Gail's attorney Giovanni Iacovo is there, along with several Roman Squadra Mobile OFFICER
I'm sorry, Ms. Getty. Mr. Getty is unavailable at the moment.

Tell him it's regarding his grandson's kidnapping in Rome. I'1l wait. Gail looks out the window: in the street, dozens of REPOR and PAPARAZZI are teeming. At the sight of her face in th window they turn their cameras on her, flashes firing.  26.
Signora! The television! Gail stretches the phone cord into the living room to see her two other kids watching Getty's press conference on T
(stunned) Never mind. I've found him.
Standing before the reporters, Getty seems vague, distrac
Daily Mail here, Mr. Getty. We have reports that a note has arrived written in the boy's handwriting, demanding 17 million US dollars.
(whistles) $17 million? That's a lot of money for such a young boy.
What steps will you be taking to secure your grandson's safety?
None. The reporters are momentarily stunned silent.
I'm afraid we didn't get that, sir.
I have fourteen grandchildren. If I pay the ransom I will have fourteen kidnapped grandchildren. A MURMUR from the reporters as they process this statemen
You're a famously ruthless negotiator, Mr. Getty.
It's just that there's so little in life worth paying full price for.
How much would you pay for your grandson, if not 17 million?  27.
Gail watches Getty on TV. His eyes are devoid of emotion.
Nothing. Good day, gentlemen. Getty turns and walks away. The press conference is over.
(calling out) Mr. Getty! What will you do to save your grandson's life? ON THE TV SCREEN: the door closes and Getty is gone.
Ms. Getty? Are you still there?
I'm still here.

When I wrote my book, "How to Be Rich," the publisher called me and said they wanted to change the title. They wanted to call it "How To Get Rich." They thought it would sell more copies. (MORE )
(shakes his head) I told them getting rich is easy. Any fool can get rich, and a remarkable number of fools do.
I've noticed that.

But being rich -- that's hard. See, the ordinary working man has to go to work to feed his family. Maybe he hates his job, hates his boss, but the drive for survival gives him a purpose in life. When a man gets rich, he's faced with the problem of freedom. An abyss opens up before him. I've seen it ruin men, and marriages, and most of all it ruins the children.
He's a kid. Kids do stupid things.
I thought I could trust my own blood.
He's probably lying on a beach somewhere. When he gets bored or runs out of money he'll come home. And he'll have learned his lesson.

I wanted to give him everything, give him all my knowledge, all I've built, and he just wanted to pick my pocket. Like his father, like his uncle, like the parasites that have swarmed around me my entire life. Getty walks on, through his sculpture garden.

That's why I like things, see. They are what they appear to be, and they never change. They never disappoint. There's a purity to beautiful things that I've never been able to find in another human being.
Neither have I. (MORE )
(off his look) You were right not to pay the ransom. You were right to follow your gut. Getty turns away from Chace, suddenly distant.
You performed well. This will be reflected in your year-end bonus.
Thank you, Mr. Getty.
Go back to Rome. Wait there for Paul to return. But your investigation is closed. The search is over. BLACK OUT.
framed by the mouth of the cave. We HEAR the kidnappers arguing, their voices echoing off the cave walls. In the darkness Paul listens.
Chipmunk, toting a shotgun, leads Little Paul on a windin trail through the mountains. The weather is turning cold; the boy is wrapped in a blanket. They approach a creek be
Do you have to go? Here's your chance. I'm not taking you out again. Paul shakes his head. Chipmunk scratches at his mask.

You don't eat, that's why. Our food isn't good enough for you. Wait here. Chipmunk climbs down into the ravine, out of sight of the boy. He peels back his ski mask for a moment, then unzips and begins to urinate. He zips up and climbs back up the ravine. Paul stares at him for a moment, then quickly looks away.
What are you looking at -- ?  58. Chipmunk reaches for his mask, and realizes he never pull it back down.
Pezzo di merda! You saw my face!
I didn't see anything!
Figlia di puttana! Culo! He pulls the ski mask down, then realizes it's pointless. He pulls it off and starts kicking it across the ground.
You saw my face! Don't lie!
I won't tell anyone what you look like, I swear.
You little shit. You've ruined everything. Chipmunk raises his shotgun at Paul.
Run. Run away. Fretta!
No. You're gonna shoot me in the back and tell them I tried to escape. Paul shakes his head, closing his eyes and refusing to tu his back. Chipmunk gives up. He kicks the ski mask again.
Manache! Have it your way. Worse for you. You'll wish you ran! Chipmunk grabs Paul and drags him back down the hill towa the squat stucco house in the distance.

Paul is tethered to a rock by a rope around his neck as g graze around him. He watches the little house: inside, Piccolo, Cinquanta and Chipmunk are arguing. Paul leans over and pulls at the tether. Desperate, he be to chew on it. The men's voices grow ever louder.  59. Then they fall silent. The front door of the house opens and three men walk out -- Cinquanta and Chipmunk in the l with the bow-legged Piccolino falling behind.
I told you. Chipmunk is carrying his shotgun. He chambers a shell. Paul begins to whimper desperately.
Please. Don't. The money. You can still get the money. Chipmunk closes the shotgun and raises it at Paul.
You had to ruin it for everyone. Now Piccolino raises his gun as well. He FIRES and we
and a groggy Fletcher Chace fumbles in the dark. A copy o Getty's book "How To Be Rich" is open on the nightstand.
Who's. Yes. Si?
Mister Chace. We are requesting you and Ms. Getty to report to the Questura.
For what?
To identify the body.
The body?
Paul's body. Paul Getty. Chace is suddenly alert.
Paul's. (blinks) OK, yes. Va bene. We're coming.  60. Chace hangs up. He sits up and starts pacing the room. Th raven-haired beauty from the bar is in his bed.
You've got to go.
PerchГ©, Fletcher? Chace starts putting on his clothes in a hurry. He starts to pick up the phone, then puts it down again.
Gail opens the door wearing her robe.
Chace -- ?
I'm sorry, Gail.
(realizing) Oh God. She covers her face with her hands. Chace looks away.
The Squadra Mobile car speeds through the night. Chace st furtive glances at Gail.
Mistakes were made, obviously, somehow. My investigation and the police's led us to the conclusion that there was no physical danger --
I'm sorry, Mr Chace. I'm on my way to identify my son's body. I don't feel like talking.
The morgue dates to the 19th century; it's dank as a cata The body is laid out on a marble slab, covered by a sheet

The corpse has been in sea water for some hours when it washed ashore. The appearance may be a shock. We gaze up at their faces as they gather round the table. The elderly CORONER pulls back the sheet.  61.

God damn! Chace reels. Gail almost faints. She shakes her head "no. REVERSE ANGLE: the bloated, waterlogged body on the table isn't Paul. It's Chipmunk. He has an ugly exit wound in his chest from where he was shot in the back by Piccolino
It's not him. It's not Paul.
The guy has five o'clock shadow, for Christ's sake. He was headed for a midlife crisis when they shot him.
A sailor by the harbor saw a body being thrown from a white Fiat 600, like the car the kidnappers drove.
This country's infested with Fiat 600s. First you said it was a hoax, then you tell us they murdered him. Why don't you make up your mind?
No one stopped you doing your own job, Mr Chace. You did that yourself. Chace is momentarily speechless.
Scusi. Everyone turns. The ancient coroner is picking at the bod on the slab with a pair of tweezers. He plucks something from Chipmunk's beard, holds it up to the light: RED FIBE
Un filato de tessuto rosso.
The carpet the body was transported in. The coroner shakes his head, mimes scratching at his bear
Una maschera.  62.
A ski mask.
of Chipmunk. There's more than one to choose from, going all the way back to his childhood.
The Police clerks search through boxes of criminal photo files. Photos of Chipmunk are pinned to the wall.
Ettore "Il Tamia" Pazzano, age 33 years. Purse snatching, public indecency, vandalism, desecration of a holy place, corruption of the youth. PHOTOS of Cinquanta and Piccolino are pinned up on the bo
Known associates: Alberto Laganadi, Dino Bova, Dante Agnana, all from Fiumara, Calabria, population 1381.
How fast can we get to Fiumara?

head_text.subj: A CONVOY OF SQUADRA MOBILE VEHICLES

text: On the unpaved road through the Calabrian mountains: we g down at them from a police helicopter circling high overh
The police cars stop on the mountain road and the uniform police climb out. Del Rovere instructs Chace:
I must ask you to stay here. For your own safety. Chace watches Rovere head off down the road.
(to Gail) Stay here. Chace opens the door and climbs out. The officer at the wheel protests, but Chace ignores him. Then Gail climbs o as well, and the cop goes apoplectic.  63.
Arrest me. We can see the stone house from several hundred meters aw as the police create a wide perimeter encircling it. Near a SQUADRA OFFICER questions a GOATHERD. Gail listens in:

..-hanno mantenuto il ragazzo in una grotta nelle montagne... Gail starts walking up the mountain road, in the opposite direction from the police, and Chace follows. They reach the mouth of the cave, which is littered with cigarette b Gail enters. Chace casts a glance back: in the pasture fa below, the police cordon around the stone house draws tig
We HOLD on GAIL as she moves deeper into the dark, follow the last of daylight into its depths. Then she finds it:
Paul. PAUL'S BED, empty. The chain and shackle lie beside it, a Paul's Fantastic Comics lies on the ground. An unfinished letter in his handwriting crumpled beside it.
"If you love me, Mother -- GUNSHOTS ring out, the echoes multiplying off the cave wa Gail and Chace hurry to the mouth of the cave.
The house is riddled with gunfire, the windows shattered. Piccolino slumps in the doorway with his shotgun in the d beside him. Del Rovere kicks the gun aside.
Molti poliziotti... So many police. Tanti...
Where is the boy?
Lo abbiamo venduto. Piccolino coughs, drowning in his own blood. A sad smile.
We sold him.  64.
Sold him to whom?
walks through a factory where women sew counterfeit Fendi handbags. Mammoliti examines the workmanship on one of th handbags, comparing it against the genuine article.

This lining. It needs to be double- stiched to look like the real Fendi My buyer can tell the difference. Mammoliti is forty years old, blankly handsome, and dress in a tailored suit: he could easily be seen in the busine class lounge of any international airport in the world.
Do it again. Mammoliti hands the bag back to the woman. She nods, care not to make eye contact: she is frightened of him.
Sicuramente, Signore. Perdonami.
Saverio Mammoliti sits in the backseat, his briefcase ope beside him, perusing a balance sheet. His bald-shaven driver/bodyguard, SGRO, pulls over behind a tractor-trail
The cargo door rolls open, revealing pallets of counterfe goods. Paul Getty is in back, guarded by two of Mammoliti men. Cinquanta is here as well.
(re: Cinquanta) What's this?
He comes with the boy. Mammoliti looks Cinquanta over; a 21st Century gangster looking back at a Stone Age one.
Get him out of here. I don't want him around.  Cinquanta
It was part of our deal. I help with the kid. I look after him.
Your services are no longer required.
The mother and I. Gail Getty. We have a dialogue. I can help you get the money.
We know how to get the money. It's not that hard if you have the stomach for it.
You heard him. reluctantly rises. Paul watches him go.
Does he do what you say?
Always. He's a good boy.
He's not eating. Look at him. We need him to eat meat, lots of meat. Build up his blood. Do you understand my meaning?
Yes. I understand your meaning.
Va bene. You work for us now.
emerge from the 1973 Extraordinary Summit of OPEC.
The princes' white robes billow in the breeze; they wear triumphant smiles of men who have seized an historic mome
GETTY'S LIMOUSINE pulls up in front of the Exchange. J Pa Getty emerges, resplendent in a Saville Row three-piece a accompanied by two lacquered YOUNGISH WOMEN in tight dres  66.

Getty takes his seat overlooking the exchange, flanked by his two concubines, like an Emperor at the Arena. The tra on the floor await the opening bell with dread and excite Getty's FLOOR TRADER hurries up the steps to take his ord Getty pats his stomach, like a man who can't eat any more
No trades for me, George. My long book's all topped up. Truth is, I woke up this morning about as long as I've been since I was a teenager. The ladies titter and smirk. One leans in, confidential:
He just likes to watch. Getty shoots her a reproving "bad girl" look. She puts ou her hand and he pinches it playfully.
Watch carefully, girls. In sixty seconds half the men in this room will be bankrupt. The seconds tick down. The floor traders brace themselves We PUSH IN on Getty as the OPENING BELL RINGS...
The boarding gate door opens and Fletcher Chace emerges wearing a suit, sunglasses and a repentant look. Then he sees something that stops him cold:
headlined on every London newspaper's evening edition: "O shuts off global oil supply."
When I got on the plane this morning oil was $4 per barrel.
Chace walks the halls alongside Getty.
You should have bought it. No one will ever see that price again. Getty's secretary hurries up to him in her high heels. Sh hands him a slip of ticker tape.  67.
The New York open, Mr. Getty.
I think it's time to reassess our strategy --
Shh. Getty reads the tape and gazes into the distance. Then he's
What are you doing, sir?
Multiplication. done. The number seems to surprise even him.
A good day.
I'm glad to hear that, Mr Getty. It'll make this much easier. (a beat) We need to pay the ransom.
You said it was a hoax.
Your grandson was kidnapped by members of the Calabrian N'dragheta, the oldest of all Italian Mafias. Two of the original kidnappers are dead and one is missing.
That sounds like progress to me.
I'm afraid not. They got nervous waiting for the ransom and sold the boy to an investor.
You told me Paul and his mother cooked this up to soak me.
I was wrong. Paul may have talked about being kidnapped with his friends. He may have put it out there but I don't believe he's behind this.  68.
How do I know you're not wrong now?
Look, these people aren't the old- world malavita anymore. They're businessmen. Their only code is profit and loss. They'll do things to Paul that can't be undone for any amount of money.
Paul got himself into this. The boy's going to have to live with the consequences of his actions.
Don't let him die just for being a child. We have to pay.
I can't.
I'm sorry?
It simply isn't possible right now. My financial position has changed.
I'm not all that bright but I can multiply as well as you. With oil up 7% this morning you made a fortune.
Precisely. I'm highly leveraged to the price of oil right now.
In the middle of an oil embargo I'd say that's a good place to be.
When the oil price is rising, it is. But what if the price of oil were suddenly to fall? What if the embargo is lifted? What then? I would be exposed. Do you know how Jesse Livermore died?
I don't know who he was.  69.

He was the greatest speculator in stocks ever to work on Wall Street. He blew his brains out in a coat check room after he lost every penny he had. That's how fast a man's fortune can turn. Don't you see? I've never been more vulnerable financially than I am right now.
No one has ever been richer than you are at this moment.
I don't have the money to spare.
What would it take? How much would it take for you to feel secure?
More. Chace is struck silent. Getty turns on him:
I didn't need to hire an ex-CIA officer just to pay people off. I can do that myself. I hired you to do things other people can't, or won't. That means rescuing the boy.
I can't do it without money.
There is no money. You'll have to get the boy on your own.
The wall-mounted phone RINGS. Gail answers it.
Signora.
Where is my son?
He is still in good health. I am with him, don't worry. In the BG, Chace turns the reel-to-reel tape recorder on.  70.
It's because of you I worry. I want to talk to him.
I'm afraid this I cannot do. I am not in charge anymore.
Chace appears at Gail's shoulder. Gail hands him the phon

This is Fletcher Chace. Mr. Getty has authorized me to negotiate on his behalf. We will cover all your expenses up to $200,000. Anything under this figure is not considered extortion under Italian law so you can walk away free and clear.
The boy is worth much more. They're not stupid.
The boy is worth nothing to anyone. We're just trying to settle this without causing any more embarrassment to the family.
My God --
He's a juvenile delinquent. His grandfather's disowned him. It's a tough break you took the wrong kid, but you're getting off easy.
You arrogant bastard.

Your uncle Piccolino died in custody last night, by the way. You ought to take this deal before the same happens to you. Chace calmly hangs up the receiver. A hand reaches into frame, picks up the receiver, and HITS him with it.  71.

(laughs) Whoa there -- ! But the next one connects. Gail hits him again, pushing h back over the stove. Dishes come out of the cupboard and rain down in shatters. Everything collapses to the kitchen floor. Chace grabs at Gail's wrists as they grapple atop broken plates. Somewhe Gail's children are crying. Then she's off him. Chace is lying on his back looking up at the ceiling, bleeding from a split lip. She disappears, taking her crying children with her. Chac is left lying on the kitchen floor. Gail re-enters.
I need some ice or I'll bleed all over your floor. Gail reaches into the freezer, pulls out a tray of ice, a drops it onto the floor. Chace rubs ice cubes on his face

I lied. I said I was authorized to pay them $200,000. You know how much I'm really authorized to pay? Nothing. If they accept I won't be able to deliver but I had to buy some time. You wanted to know what I used to do? This is what I used to do. What I still do, for Getty.
You "make deals." You "buy people."
That's right. Whether it's a pit of grease in the desert or a human life it's all the same. We have to show we're willing to walk away.
I can't walk away. You can walk away, because you have nothing to lose, because there's no one in your world but yourself.
Fair enough. Chace goes to the door. As he leaves:  72.
Seventeen million dollars and zero dollars. That's how far apart we are. Those numbers have got to move.
Gail lies in bed in the fetal position. The phone rings. She goes to the kitchen and picks it up.
Seven million dollars. DIAL TONE. Gail is left holding the receiver. The numbers have just moved.
GREAT SHAFTS OF LIGHT penetrate the darkness of the Basil vaulted dome. In a pew toward the rear Gail and Chace sit eight feet apart, like a couple waiting to get a divorce.
When a man like you resorts to prayer I start to worry we're running out of options.
We're not here to pray. We're here to speak to the Archbishop Marcinckus. The six-foot-six ARCHBISHOP MARCINCKUS approaches.
Otherwise known as the Pope's Gorilla.
Marcinkus and Gail with their heads bowed in prayer.

Sancta Maria, Mater Dei, ora pro nobis peccatoribus, nunc, et in hora mortis nostrae. Chace sits watching a few rows back, like a man waiting i bus station. As their prayers are finished, he joins them
Ms Getty, the Holy Pontiff himself is praying today for the safe return of your beautiful boy.
Thank you, Archbishop Marcinkus. (MORE )
I was hoping you could use your personal influence to help Paul.
Paul has been kidnapped by the N'dragheta, father. Marcinkus nods. He speaks in a blunt Chicago accent:
I may be able to have some influence there. (off Gail's look) Don't look so surprised. The Vatican has for hundreds of years had relationships with the ancient fraternal organizations of Italy.
Actually, we were hoping his Holiness would persuade my father-in-law to pay the ransom.
You want me to ask the Pontiff to twist J Paul Getty's arm?
Mr. Getty tends to listen to those he considers his equals.
And he thinks the Pope is his equal.
Nearly.
You gave me the impression that you were here on Mr. Getty's behalf. Who is it you're working for? For a moment, Chace doesn't know how to answer.
I just want to bring the boy home. Marcinkus rises.
I'll have a word with his Holiness. (re: Chace's face) You look like you met up with something that didn't agree with you.  74. Gail looks away.
Rome is a tough town, Father.
The toughest.
Gail and Chace walk in the shade of the colonnades beside the vast plaza. Chace keeps his distance.
I owe you an apology, Mr Chace. I was angry, but that's no excuse.
I've taken worse beatings before for less cause. Never with a princess phone, though.
Please don't make a joke out of it.
OK, how about this, then. You were right when you said I had nothing. I'm not important, I'm not rich.
That's not what I meant.
But if I had the money to give I'd give it to you. Gail looks up at him.
Let me rephrase that.
Don't. Gail walks through the colonnade, and Chace walks with he
A PRIVATE PLANE taxis on the mist-shrouded runway. The clamshell air-stair descends, a black sedan pulls up, and two bodyguards whisk J Paul Getty inside.  75.
Getty and his coterie enter via the alley door, briskly m through the kitchen.
A group of furtive Milanese in black designer clothes hov outside a hotel suite.
Good evening, Mr. Getty.
Nothing good about it. Let's get down to business.
Are you serious about making payment?
I wouldn't be here if I weren't.
Because there can't be any more games. You know our price, and it's not subject to negotiation any longer. Payment must be made in cash, tonight.
I want the proof first.
After you.
As he enters, Getty is overcome with emotion.
There you are. REVERSE ANGLE: there on the bedspread is a small painting Albrecht Diirer's 15th Century "Madonna and Child in a Wi
Because of the painting's disputed provenance, it can never be publicly displayed. As discussed, our price is $1.15 million.
I'm afraid we weren't able to bring the full sum. Liquidity, you know. Otto motions for his men to begin packing up the painting  76.
True masterpieces never go on sale, Mr. Getty. If you cannot pay, you will never own one. Getty grimaces. He turns to one of his coterie:
Pay the man.
A BUTCHER cuts flesh from a lamb's flank with a cleaver, wraps it in wax paper, and hands it to Sgro and Cinquanta
A field of dried grain roils in the wind. A tumbledown clapboard shack stands at its center.
Paul sits on a bare mattress, chained to the floor. Cinqu enters with an oil lantern and a covered plate.
I brought you something to warm you, Paolo. Something special for being a good boy. He sets down the plate. Two steaks, running with blood.
Can I have some crackers?
What do you want that for? I brought you this good tagliata. Come on, we eat it together. Paul takes a bite. It's hard to swallow.
It's too much. I'll be sick.
Look at me, Paul. You must eat it all, no matter how long it takes. Make sure you keep it down.
You bring me steak now? Why? The door opens and a man walks in carrying a doctor's bag The Doctor indicates for Paul to come to him.  77.
Do as he says. The Doctor examines Paul's ears. He shaves the hair aroun the ear with a straight razor, then swabs it with alcohol
Eat now. Keep eating. Ask me no questions, Paolo. You have to trust me. It's important. He offers a bite to the boy, as you would to a child.
I'll eat it. Just leave me alone and I'll eat it all, OK? The Doctor exits, his examination finished. Cinquanta lea the plate on the floor. Paul takes a bite of the steak.

If I could, I'd take your place. Cinquanta turns and walks outside, leaving Paul alone. Pa spits out the morsel. He takes out the Bic pen and the bo of matches hidden inside the waistband of his pants. QUICK CUTS: Paul uses the steak knife to scrape the phosphorous off the match heads. He removes the ink tube from the pen and packs it with the phosphorous. He goes to work on the shackle that chains him to the bar floor, attacking the floorboards with the knife. He hears the VOICES of the men. He looks through a crack the wall. They're drinking and singing outside the farmho He pulls on the chain again, leaning into it. Finally it gives. He falls, the chain CLATTERING across the floor. THROUGH THE CRACK IN THE WALL: the men fall silent, then resume their carousing. Paul picks up the pen tube and ra it to his lips like a peashooter. He lights a match -- -- and the phosphorous packed inside CATCHES FIRE. It spa brilliantly, like a Roman candle. He aims it through the crack in the wall, then BLOWS --
-- LAUNCHING it into the field of dried, broken grain. Fo a moment it is a shooting star, and then it lands.
PAUL'S EYE peers through the crack in the wall --  78.

-- as his Roman candle sputters amidst the cracked stalks then dies. The light in Paul's eye seems to die with it. Then the wind picks up. The embers begin to glow and scat the cracked wheat catches fire.

THE ENTIRE FIELD IS ABLAZE. Paul climbs out of the wood shed with the broken chain slung over his shoulder. He disappears into the wheat field. The flames threaten to overtake the barn; the men from th house come running, desperate to rescue the boy inside. Paul runs through the wheat field as A WALL OF FLAME cons it. The wind whips the smoke into a black cloud behind hi We PULL BACK to gaze down upon the young boy as runs, the great field of fire spreading in his wake.

Paul runs toward the highway with the chain slung over hi neck. A pillar of smoke climbs into the sky in the distan A single CAR drives by. Paul tries to wave it down, but t driver speeds up to avoid him. Up ahead, he sees it: a CARABINERI POLICE CAR driving away.
Hey. Police. Police! Poliziotto! Paul runs into the highway, waving his arms.

Over here! Attenzione! A car horn BLARES: the driver nearly clips him -- -- but the RED TAILLIGHTS on the police car light up. The mustached CONSTABLE stops and climbs out of the car. As soon as the constable gets a glimpse of Paul's conditi he hurries over to him. The boy collapses into his arms.
A fire glows in the hearth. The Constable's WIFE, a stock Italian Mamma, stretches a blanket over Paul's shoulders. In the BG, the Constable phones in to report the boy's re
Povera bambino... cosi freddo...  79. She goes to the hearth and spoons out a plate of warm pol
Mangia. Paul takes a spoonful. As he eats, tears roll down his fa The Constable and his wife smile warmly.
Can I make a phone call? I want to call my mother. The old woman brings the telephone to the boy's side and hands him the receiver. With trembling hands, he dials.
HOLD ON the phone as it RINGS. Gail turns on the tape recorder, then picks up the phone.
Mom? (a beat) Mom, are you there?
Paul.
It's alright, Mom. I'm OK. I'm safe now.
As Paul talks with his mother, there's a KNOCK at the doo In the BG, the Constable goes to answer it.
I'm at the police station. I need you to come and get me. In the BG, several men enter and exchange greetings.
What police station? Where are you?
I just want to come home. You don't know how close they came.
I'm coming to take you home. What police station are you at?
Hold on, I'll ask. (MORE )
(calling out) Excuse me, where am I? Dove sono io? Behind him, A HAND REACHES INTO FRAME and presses down on the receiver cradle, gently hanging up the phone.
The line goes dead.
Paul? Paul -- ?
We TILT UP from the phone cradle along the length of the man's arm -- -- REVEALING that it is Saverio Mammoliti himself that ha hung up the phone. He reaches out to the boy.

Give it here. Paul hands the receiver to Mammoliti, who hangs up. We PAN across the faces in the room: Mammoliti's men, alo with the Constable, his wife, and, to one side, Cinquanta Mammoliti offers his hand to Paul.
Come now, Paul. There will be no more foolishness. The boy places a hand over the ear that's been shorn and cleaned, as if trying to protect it.

Come. Paul takes Mammoliti's hand. They walk out of the station hand-in-hand, into the street, where Mammoliti's car awai The rear door opens, they climb inside, and the Mercedes vanishes into the darkness.
Gail stands frozen with the dead receiver in her hand.
The apartment is overrun by Squadra Mobile officers, incl Del Rovere and Corvo. The tape squeals as it rewinds, the  81.
I just want to come home. You don't know how close they came.
I'm coming to take you home. What police station are you at?
(listening on headphones ) Ascoltare. Pavimenti. Footsteps. Someone approaches --
Excuse me, where am I? Dove sono io -- CLICK. The line goes dead.
Someone breaks the connection.
He was in a police station. Nothing could happen to him there, right?
It could have been a bad connection. It's Italy. Nothing works right.
No. Everything works differently.
He was safe. He said he was safe. He was in this room, just now, talking to me. He can't just be gone.
Keep the line open. He'll call back. We will wait as long as it takes.
The fire in the fields has burned itself out; ASHES dance the air like snowflakes. Paul rides in the backseat with Mammoliti. Cinquanta rides up front with Sgro.
(sotto voce) I'm starting to see why they don't want their kid back. Maybe they'd pay us to keep him, or kill him.  82.
Don't blame the kid. You'd have done the same if you could have thought of it. Mammoliti gazes out the rear window.

A big fire like this? It draws attention. Inspectors. Bribes to be paid. We budget for contingencies, but nothing like this. The farmhouse comes into view. The wooden shed is scorche but still standing. We pull up in front of it.
There are carrying costs. It's discipline, fiscal discipline. Either the family pays, or we must cut our losses.

The cops are all gone. Only their overflowing ashtrays an coffee cups remain. Gail and Chace have been up all night Chace sits at the table, tie askew, helping Ariadne, Gail youngest, complete a word-search puzzle in a coloring boo as her other son watches television.
They always hide the words backwards.
You don't have to do that.
I enjoy it. It's about my speed.
He's not going to call. Go home.
I don't have a home. I have a hotel.
